message_1: A factory has 10 workers and wishes to know in how many ways they can award a prize to the workers, with a prize going to each worker. How many ways are there to distribute a prize to each worker if the factory management wants to reward at least one worker? Use Bell numbers to solve the problem.
message_2:
Bell numbers are used to count the number of ways to partition a set into non-empty subsets. In this case, we want to partition the set of 10 workers into non-empty subsets, where each subset represents a group of workers receiving a prize.

The Bell numbers can be calculated using the following recurrence relation:

B(n) = Î£ (from k=0 to n-1) C(n-1, k) * B(k)

where B(n) is the nth Bell number, and C(n, k) is the binomial coefficient (n choose k).

The first few Bell numbers are:

B(0) = 1
B(1) = 1
B(2) = 2
B(3) = 5
B(4) = 15
B(5) = 52
B(6) = 203
B(7) = 877
B(8) = 4140
B(9) = 21147
B(10) = 115975

So, there are 115975 ways to distribute a prize to the 10 workers, with at least one worker receiving a prize.
